text: The Calvin cycle is dependent on the Light-dependent reactions, and almost in the same way Light-dependent reactions are dependent on 'The Calvin Cycle'. So it is almost like a constant cycle between the two areas.
question: Does the Calvin cycle happen after the light-dependent reactions occurs or is the Calvin cycle independent?

text: Introns have multiple roles in biology including the regulation of gene expression. Other introns have functions after they are spliced out from the transcript and can act as signaling or regulatory molecules. Some relatively rare types of introns appear to be parasitic DNA molecules - they insert copies of themselves into genes and then splice themselves out from the RNA presumably to keep the host cell alive. It is possible that the more typical introns originated from such parasitic DNA elements. This is still an area of active research and it is quite likely that more functions for introns will be uncovered in the future.
question: Why are introns are formed?

text: the first stage would be the 'activation of amino acids'. Basically this step is before the initiation stage. During this activation of amino acids a specific amino acid and an ATP will bind to an enzyme called "aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas". The specific amino acid will bind the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas where it will be activated by covalently binding with the ATP turning it into AMP during the process (releasing pyrophosphate). Then a tRNA will bind the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas and it will covalently bind with the activated amino acid (releasing AMP). When the amino acid and the tRNA bind they will be released from the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas and can then bind with the corresponding mRNA codon. So, when the tRNA leaves the E site is basically starts over the above process.
question: From where does tRNA get revived to continue its function in the future?

text: there is one enzyme which is crucial for translation and that is "aminoacyl tRNA synthetase". This enzyme attaches an amino acid to the tRNA. There is a different version of this for every different amino acid (so 20 of these in human bodies). The enzyme is a "synthetase" because it creates a new structure called "aminoacyl-tRNA", which is the tRNA which has an amino acid linked to it. The word "aminoacyl" means that an amino acid is linked to something, in this case tRNA. This process happens BEFORE the tRNA enters the ribosome and it takes place in the cytosol. ATP is required for that reaction.

text: The states of matter depend on two things, pressure, and temperature. If the temperate increases than the general energy increases and the molecules break away from each other thus causing the element to change to a higher state of matter, such as from liquid to gas. But the same is true with pressure except in a different way. If the pressure exerted on water is increased the molecules are squished together and it changes to a solid, but if the pressure is decreased the molecules are "pulled apart" and the state changes to a gas without the temperature having to change at all.

text: There are two double bonds between C and O, and two lone pairs of electrons on each Oxygen. During the formation of CO, what happens is the absence of the second oxygen is solved by the donation of one of those lone pairs of electrons from the oxygen to the carbon. So two of the bonds are simple covalent bonds, in which each atom supplies one electron to the bond, and the third bond is a co-ordinate covalent bond (i.e. both electrons provided only by O). Count the electrons and notice that both have 8 in their outer shell. That's is all molecules want
question: How does oxygen get a triple bond with carbon?

text: As a cell grows in size, the surface area gets bigger, but the volume gets bigger faster. Thinking about this as a ratio (division), the volume is the denominator and the surface area is the numerator. If the volume is getting very big, then the ratio itself will be getting very small. What this translates to is as a cell gets larger, with a larger volume, it has a smaller SA:V. A smaller SA:V means that diffusion of nutrients and diffusion of waste in less efficient (harder to do). The rate of diffusion doesn't change, but it would take longer for the nutrients to diffuse through to the centre of the cell than a cell with a higher SA:V (a smaller cell - i.e. a cell with a smaller volume)
question: What does surface area have to do with how much energy it takes for these transfers to occur?

text: tetrahedral e.g. carbon at the centre of the tetrahedron, hydrogens at the four vertices. Trigonal pyramidal e.g. nitrogen at a vertex of the triangular pyramid (apex of pyramid), hydrogens at the vertices of the triangular base of pyramid. A tetrahedron is a regular triangular pyramid. But the way the word "tetrahedral" is used is different from what you normally think of when you picture a tetrahedron. They say that CH4 (methane) has a tetrahedral shape. Now, you may think the four C-H bonds form a tetrahedron, but that's wrong: they don't. If you join the four hydrogen atoms with straight lines, you'd get a tetrahedron in that case. Trigonal pyramidal, on the other hand, is different. They might say NH3 is trigonal pyramidal, by which they mean that the 3 N-H bonds form three sides of a triangular pyramid, where the N is the apex of the pyramid. The triangular "base" of the pyramid is formed by the three H atoms joined to each other. I don't want to confuse you, but trigonal pyramidal shaped NH3 has a tetrahedral "geometry".
question: How is trigonal pyramidal different from tetrahedral?

text: A v-shape ('bent') shape occurs when an atom has 3 attached groups, with one of those groups being a lone pair. It also occurs when an atom has 4 attached groups and 2 of those groups are lone pairs. Be careful though, these shapes are called the same name, but they have different bond angles. A general chem class might require that you know 1 lone pair = less than 120 degrees, 2 lone pairs = less than 109.5 degrees. Also, It is possible for an atom to have 5 or even 6 groups attached to it (these cases are called expanded octets), such as Phosphorus pentachloride (PCl5) or sulfur hexafluoride (SF6).
question: Species have lone pairs molecular geometry can only be v-shaped or trigonal pyramid?

text: Symporters and antiporters use the energy stored in the electrochemical gradient. Depending on which membrane is being discussed, the electrochemical gradient may created by either metabolic processes (e.g. the electron transport chain in mitochondria) and/or by using ATP to pump ions "uphill" (against their electrochemical gradient). Secondary active transport means that, rather than directly using ATP to power the movement of compounds across the membrane, proteins like symporters and antiporters use the energy stored in the electrochemical gradient. The electrochemical gradient is the combined "push" due to concentration and charge differences across the membrane.
question: Do the symporters and antiporters use ATP?

text: Certain Plants do grow better around each other and help each other out. Researcher Dr. David Johnson looked closely at plants' symbiotic relationship with soil fungus, piggybacking off a 2010 study that seemed to suggest that a tomato plant infected with leaf blight would be able to warn nearby plants of the problem. In turn, those plants would activate genes that would prevent them from catching the disease, too. Johnson was able to show how plants use fungus in the soil as a network (think of it as a botanical Wi-Fi, if you will). Essentially, fungi deliver messages of danger from plant to plant, and as a result, the group can grow stronger. Even plants get by with a little help from their friends. *Animals* help plants by pollinating them, and be helping to disperse seeds. The droppings of animals also fertilize plants. Plants have three basic responses or reactions to light. They are photosynthesis, phototropism and photoperiodism. As plants react/respond to light the amount of heat wont matter anyway.
question: Do plants respond to night light with no heat?

text: The efficiency of the respiratory system is very very efficient. Imagine a system of pipes; one pulls the air, another transfers it. Since pipes are rounded and therefore 'closed' air cannot escape through the piping. Take for example your hand. Curl it, and blow through it. Almost none or if any air escapes, except through the other side. Because of this, the only path for the air to take is to the lungs. In which the lungs work/use the air and the entire cycle happens again. When a biological system is working many other dependent systems are working too.
question: Does some air leak or escape?

text: When you sprain your ankle your ligaments (bone to bone connections) get stretched and may get partially torn. This causes the body to respond with inflammation and this response is the normal and a necessary response to tissue damage. Next question may be "What is and how does inflammatory response work?. In short the damaged and dead cells need repair. This causes your blood vessels to dilate accounting for the redness you see around the insulted tissue. The swelling is also the result of capillary dilation. As capillaries dilate the gaps between get larger allowing fluid to leak out in the surrounding area.
question: How is a ligament tear different from a sprain and why does it require surgery?
